title: Cyber Daily: Cybersecurity Companies Are Raking in Millions. Many Don't Turn Profits.
text:
A burst bubble could bring bad outcomes for cyber companies but also for customers who rely on their products. Running tech tools from defunct providers and scrambling for replacements can make a company vulnerable to hackers.

The Current State of Stateful DDoS Attacks

State-exhaustion DDoS attacks represent a clear and present danger to business operations and profitability. Being able to block them requires unique capabilities.

Read more

Many cyber vendors are in the red, pumping money into sales and marketing, boosting research and development, or gobbling up competitors. For those companies, profitability remains a long-term goal.

Mark McClain, chief executive of cybersecurity firm SailPoint Technologies Holdings Inc., has what he calls an old-school mind-set: Companies can't lose money forever.

But even though his business is unprofitable, like many in the sector, that hasn't put off investors. Share prices of most publicly traded cybersecurity companies have shot up during the coronavirus pandemic.

Public markets are rewarding the sector as corporations ramp up digitizing their operations and investing in cybersecurity to ward off a surge in threats. The dynamic is pushing Mr. McClain, who tries to balance profitability and growth, to lean in the latter direction to stake SailPoint's claim on a booming market.

"There is kind of a land grab," said Mr. McClain, whose company posted net losses for each of the past two fiscal years while accelerating revenue growth. SailPoint's share price has more than tripled since March 2020.

More Cyber and Privacy News

Small Business Administration is the focus of House cybersecurity bill. The SBA Cyber Awareness Act would compel the association to assess its cybersecurity posture and develop a plan for improvement. Vulnerabilities at the SBA surfaced as it worked to distribute pandemic-relief funds only to see fraudsters take advantage of the program, said Rep. Young Kim (R., Calif.), a co-sponsor of the bill. The SBA's Inspector General has cited cybersecurity as a challenge for more than two decades, she said. (Security Week)

$10 Million

Top reward offered by the State Department for information leading to the identification or location of leaders of the DarkSide ransomware gang. DarkSide was behind the May ransomware incident at Colonial Pipeline, according to U.S. officials. Tipsters can get up to $5 million for information leading to the arrest or conviction of anyone taking part in a DarkSide attack.

In brief:

Federal cybersecurity directive spotlights aging computer systems. Outdated equipment and talent shortages have complicated efforts to address vulnerabilities. (WSJ CIO Journal)

Indictment of Igor Danchenko casts new doubts on sourcing of Steele dossier. An FBI attorney who prepared a surveillance application, as well as an attorney who specializes in cybersecurity, have also been indicted by the special counsel's office on charges of making false statements. (WSJ)

Cybersecurity-focused investment firm Evolution Equity Partners said it has hired Phil Quade as chief operating officer. He will manage day-to-day operations and become part of its investment team. Mr. Quade joins the firm from cyber company Fortinet Inc., where he was CISO. (WSJ Pro Private Equity)

Bitcoin battle: Eric Adams, incoming New York City mayor, said on Twitter he wants his first three paychecks in bitcoin. He added: "NYC is going to be the center of the cryptocurrency industry and other fast-growing, innovative industries! Just wait!" The declaration came after Miami Mayor Francis Suarez, re-elected this week, tweeted that he plans to take his first paycheck in bitcoin. (Reuters)
